subject: Learning
title: Renaissance Humanism and the Liberal Arts
description: A quick, practical guide to Renaissance Humanism and the Liberal Arts.

hook.text: Renaissance scholars rediscovered Greek texts and declared: education should make better humans, not just priests.

buildup.text: Humanism shifted education from theological training to developing well-rounded, civic-minded individuals.

discovery.text: The studia humanitatisâ€”grammar, rhetoric, history, poetry, and moral philosophyâ€”became the new core curriculum.

twist.text: Still, this 'universal' education was only for elite males. The Renaissance was progressive by degrees.

climax.text: The liberal arts tradition born here survives in American colleges 500 years later.

punchline.text: The Renaissance asked: what if education served people, not just institutions?

quiz.question: What shift did Renaissance humanism bring to education?
options: Focus moved from theology to developing well-rounded civic individuals
